This is the first of two courses designed to provide a platform of understanding of physical principles and manufacturing technologies encountered by Industrial Designers. A basic understanding of the principles and related physical properties of materials, mechanical devices, electricity and electronic products is covered. Such knowledge will enable students to comprehend and conceive of product design solutions that are informed by realistic expectations in terms of estimated product function, performance and use. In addition, the course will enable students to discuss their design proposals with technical experts, such as manufacturing engineers and materials specialists.

contentlets.description: This is the first of two courses designed to provide a platform of understanding of physical principles and manufacturing technologies encountered by Industrial Designers. A basic understanding of the principles and related physical properties of materials, mechanical devices, electricity and electronic products is covered. Such knowledge will enable students to comprehend and conceive of product design solutions that are informed by realistic expectations in terms of estimated product function, performance and use. In addition, the course will enable students to discuss their design proposals with technical experts, such as manufacturing engineers and materials specialists.

This studio-based course introduces students to the fundamentals of two-dimensional and three-dimensional design, from an industrial design discipline perspective. Studies will include: understanding the basic elements of two and three-dimensional design, and the development of analytic and communication skills necessary for understanding 2D and 3D design. It will examine the development of the creative processes concerned with the exploration and manipulation of the elements of design


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"78721573dbf91c50eb6b147a3a961952","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Model making","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"15","description":"

Students are required to make a number of different shapes using bluefoam. After this skill is completed students will be required to make a transional shape using bluefoam and complete their work by covering it in white filler. This is an individual project that is assessed and critiqued directly with the student.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"fc721573dbf91c50eb6b147a3a961935","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"18721573dbf91c50eb6b147a3a96191f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Visual Diary Submission","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"5","description":"

Students are to compile a Visual Diary which includes any thoughts, sketches, images, ideas, research, clippings that have inspired the student throughout the semester. It can include the development and documentation of projects completed in this class.

Details of submission requirements, assessment criteria and standards will be set out in a comprehensive Studbrief for each of the Projects in the Fundamentals Handbook.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a0721573dbf91c50eb6b147a3a961933","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"50721573dbf91c50eb6b147a3a961924","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project 1 Patterns","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

Part 1 (week 3) Development 10%

Students are asked to research a famous Designer and understand their Design Philosophy. With the knowledge and understanding of their  Designers philosphy, students are required to create a poster advertising an exhibition of their Designer. The poster should be.

Online resources are available for students to start their research and quizes are to be completed

-Part 2 (Week 10) Final Presentation 40%

Students are required to create patterns using elements relating to their Designer. The final presentation of the Patterns project is a body of work that includes two dimensional static pattern drawings, three dimensional dynamic patterns drawn and painted. Additionally students will design and create a 3D relief of their patterns and a 3D model of an element of the pattern.

Students will submit works in differnt mediums including drawings, paintings, reliefs and models in an exhibition style presentation.

Details of submission requirements, assessment criteria and standards will be set out in a comprehensive brief for each of the Projects in the Fundamentals Handbook.

Face to face critique.

-Part 1 (week 5) Development 5%

Online resources are provided for students to understand the basics of the topic area, Colour. Students are expected to read and understand the online modules and complete the online quizes.

-Part 2 (Week 9) Final Presentation 25%

Students are asked to demonstrate their understanding of Colour Theory by producing a painted colour wheel. Students are also to design a three dimensional geometric shape to demonstrate their understanding of the effects of light on colour.

Details of submission requirements, assessment criteria and standards will be set out in a comprehensive brief for each of the Projects in the Fundamentals Handbook.

Face to face critique.

contentlets.description:
This studio-based course enhances students' understanding of the fundamentals of two dimensional and three-dimensional design, from an Industrial Design discipline perspective.

Building on their studies in Studio 1A, this course will include: enhancing the understanding of the elements of two and three-dimensional design, and the continuing development of analytic and communication skills necessary for understanding and producing 2D and 3D design. The course will examine the creative processes concerned with the exploration and manipulation of the elements of design.

In this studio-based course, students will build upon previous studies of two and three-dimensional Industrial Design to embark upon several Industrial Design projects that explore varied approaches to the generation and expression of high-quality ideas. Students will be guided through simple product design projects that will examine the creative processes used in Industrial Design and present these using visual communication and model making techniques.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"4b21b5b3db315c50eb6b147a3a9619cd","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Good Sheet","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

This assessment task is another design and making project - to design and prototype an office product made largely of one type of sheet material. Choice of material may depend on access to the Design Futures Lab and equipment but could include cardboard, polystyrene or aclylic plastic sheet material, aluminium or steel sheet. A detailed brief will be provided at the start of term, outlinining the category of object to be designed, constraints that apply to size, purpose, material selection and finish. Assessment criteria linked to CLOs will be set out in a marking rubric, included with the assignment brief. Submission requirements will be: 

  1. An online process illustrated process journal kept up to date and available weekly for presentation to class.
  2. A final model, exhibited in studio and/or photographed for online submission
  3. Technical drawings submitted online on completion of the project In this project knowledge of manufacturing production methods is expected to be evident in the drawings.

Formative feeback will be provided weekly in class or online by tutors and comments/contributions invited from peers. Summative feedback will be proviided by tutors with separeate marks for:

  1. Process - based on the record of the design process in the process journal, on completion 
  2. Final Design - as communicated by the model and technical drawing.

A written feedback comment will be provided by tutors, with reference to the stated assessment criteria.

A component of the summative assessment will be allocated to peer assessment collected via a rating form.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"0321b5b3db315c50eb6b147a3a9619c7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"0b21b5b3db315c50eb6b147a3a9619a8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"4721b5b3db315c50eb6b147a3a9619ab","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"4f21b5b3db315c50eb6b147a3a9619c9","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3a21b5b3db315c50eb6b147a3a96199a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Engagement","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"15","description":"

Engagement with the course will be demonstrated through sudents responding to weekly pre-class exercises that will require a response through a shared moodle forum, or similar. Exercises each week may require different types of responses that will typically include:

  • Short essay responses to a question or in response to a reading
  • Finding and contributing resources, with suitable commentary by the student
  • Submitting examples of work in progress (drawings, photographs) with questions
  • In some weeks, responding to other student posts and questions.

Assessment of this component work will be by

  • Formative assessment by recognition of quality contributions through announcmements, mentions in class time or forum posts by tutors.
  • Summative assessment at end of term with marks that recognise, frequency (did the student post each week) and value of contrinbution (rated in some weeks by peer feedback).

A detailed brief will be provided at the start of term, outlinining the category of object to be made, constraints that apply to size, purpose and material selection. Assessment criteria linked to CLOs will be set out in a marking rubric, included with the assignment brief. Submission requirements will be:

  2. A final model, exhibited in studio and photographed for online submission
  3. Technical drawings submitted online on completion of the project.

Formative feeback will be provided weekly in class or online by tutors and comments/contributions invited from peers. Summative feedback will be proviided by tutors with separeate marks for:

  2. Final Design - as communicated by the model and technical drawing.

A written feedback comment will be provided, with reference to the stated assessment criteria.

The skills are applicable to design projects students will undertake in Design Studio courses. Techniques and theory explored in this course include rapid methods of hand making and finisihing of  models; digital fabrication; and use of sensor technologies to explore the working of products and sytems.

IDES2021 sensitizes industrial design students to be more mindful of their role and responsibility to human society and to the natural environment that nurtures society. It highlights how the design process can become more ethical and more responsive to social needs, and how design can empower individuals and groups to catalyse and realize positive change in the present and future of their communities. It broadens the social impact and influence of design beyond pure market orientation through the inclusion of marginalized and underrepresented user groups and through addressing significant issues affecting society such as crime, social injustice, disabilities, public safety, climate change, food security, extreme poverty, responsible consumption, equality, education access, refugees, and the developing world. Through online videos and in-class workshops, students will explore how design innovation can enrich the quality of life and wellbeing for all without sacrificing ecological sustainability or economic prosperity.

The course introduces a range of established Industrial Design research methods. These are methods in which students will apply some rigour to activities such as observation of user behaviours, simulation of Industrial Design alternatives, and analysis of available information. Lectures, case studies and online resources will provide a theoretical platform for students, but learning will include application, practice and reflective discussion of methods in Industrial Design challenges.


The focus is on developing rigour around academic research skills and writing within the context of Industrial Design research. Students will be given a list of specific topics to choose from to start their Industrial Design research process. The term will culminate with a Industrial Design Research Report, covering problems and/or opportunities identified for the selected topic, a literature review, data gathering, synthesis and analysis of information and research results.

This course follows on from Physical Principles for Designers. It places an emphasis upon the relationship between Industrial Design practice and manufacturing processes. This course enables designer to design and specify a specific materials and manufacturing processes. Students will learn to communicate intelligently and effectively with other manufacturing specialists. The course will develop your knowledge of engineering materials and manufacturing processes tailored for the Industrial Designer. The focus will be upon metals, alloys, fastening systems and assembly processes. Other materials and manufacturing processes will also be covered in less detail, they include: composite materials and ceramics.  Specific topics covered within this course include, design and selection of materials and manufacturing processes, design constraints, design for assembly and disassembly, specification and tolerancing, and advanced manufacturing technologies.

This course provides an introduction to computer modeling, with a parametric modelling application widely used in the design industry.  Students develop competency with modelling that supports exploration of design in subsequent studio courses. Learning is structured around lectures and demonstrations followed by practical computer lab classes with structured learning activities. Assignment tasks engage students in designing, modelling and communicating components with a degree of complexity typical of consumer product design solutions. 


 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"a8295db3db3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619c7","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"On-line weekly quiz results","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"10","description":"

A weekly quiz queston to be answered by each student on-line. Questions will be drawn from information provided in weekly lectures and online resources available to students.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"14295db3db3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619be","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"50295db3db3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619c1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"9c295db3db3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619c3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d4295db3db3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619bb","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"04295db3db3d1c50eb6b147a3a961980","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Modelled part","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Demonstrate learning from the first four weeks by creating a digital model of a single product component such as the top part of a cordless phone case. This individual assignment concludes with on-line submission of a digital model file and also a file suitable for digital 3D printing.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d4295db3db3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619bb","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"80295db3db3d1c50eb6b147a3a961966","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Modelled assembly","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

Show that you can design relatively simple product that is an assembly of a number of parts that fit together. Submit both the assembly file and individual component part files. This is an individual assignment - each student is to submit the oucome of their own design.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"14295db3db3d1c50eb6b147a3a9619be","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"c8295db3db3d1c50eb6b147a3a96196a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Drawings and Render","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

Create a set of specification drawing from the parts and assembly modelled by the student in Assignment 2. Drawings to include;

  1. Specifications and dimensioned views of individual components
  2. A General Assembly drawing showing parts in their assembled arrangement to one another
  3. A composite image with rendered perspective view and orthogonal (top, front, side) views.

Each student to their submit their work as a multi-page pdf file.

This course introduces theory and strategies for designing for people and particularly addresses understanding of human diversity. Attention is given to access, usability, comfort and performance of the human/product system. Class activities and assignments support learning of stategies for representing and engaging users in the design process, drawing on perspectives of Ergonomics/Human Factors, User Interface (UI) design and Inclusive Design. Students are equipped to investigate human-use implications of their own current and future design practice.

IDES2221 develops competencies in designing products of intermediate complexity. Through a series of presentations and class activities students will apply knowledge from previous courses to design projects. These design projects include the design resolution and detailing of appropriate forms and assemblies when designing for manufacture.


Students will advance their design communication skills for specifying form, details, assembly, fit and finish to accurately communicate their design intent with other design and manufacturing specialists.

Student will reflect on and demonstrate their design process using effective communications techniques that reflect an appropriate audience, purpose and context. This project requires students to submit a curated process document that reflects their approach to the briefs, describes their design process and critically reflects on the students achievements and opportunities for learning through the two design projects.

Submission and presentation.

Details of submission requirements, assessment criteria and standards will be set out in a comprehensive brief for each of Design Projects 1 and 2. Both briefs will be available to students in Moodle from O-week, together with other resources related to the projects.

Contributions to online discussion constitutes a component assessment in this course because peer to peer dialogue is an important part of the studio learning experience. You may be asked, for example, to express opinions, post an image, rate or rank examples or respond to others’ comments. Assessment of this component of the course will be based on:

• Frequency of contributions – did you respond weekly?

• Quality of response – a simple 3-point rating scale will be used by tutors to grade evident value and originality of contributions. There will also be a weekly in class review of on-line discussion in that week, drawing attention to the more interesting student contributions, thus providing formative feedback.

Annotated assignment returned to group with mark and comments on a feedback form. Mark for each group member also placed in Moodle Gradebook

Final presentation and submission.

Details of submission requirements, assessment criteria and standards will be set out in a comprehensive brief for each of Design Projects 1 and 2. Both briefs will be available to students in Moodle from O-week, together with other resources related to the projects.

Contributions to online discussion constitutes a component assessment in this course because peer to peer dialogue is an important part of the studio learning experience. You may be asked, for example, to express opinions, post an image, rate or rank examples or respond to others’ comments. Assessment of this component of the course will be based on:

• Frequency of contributions – did you respond weekly?

• Quality of response – a simple 3-point rating scale will be used by tutors to grade evident value and originality of contributions. There will also be a weekly in class review of on-line discussion in that week, drawing attention to the more interesting student contributions, thus providing formative feedback.

a) In Class presentation with initial discussion and verbal feedback from tutor.

b) Submitted drawings and report returned with annotations. Written feedback and mark returned via Moodle

contentlets.description:
IDES2221 develops competencies in designing products of intermediate complexity. Through a series of presentations and class activities students will apply knowledge from previous courses to design projects. These design projects include the design resolution and detailing of appropriate forms and assemblies when designing for manufacture.

Students will advance their design communication skills for specifying form, details, assembly, fit and finish to accurately communicate their design intent with other design and manufacturing specialists.

IDES2222 develops competencies in designing products for specific social and cultural contexts. Through a series of presentations and class activities students will apply knowledge from previous studios to design projects of increasing complexity. Design projects will require research into cultures, technologies, human factors, commercial contexts, materials and manufacturing processes.


 
This course further advances product illustration, rendering and documentation techniques to create persuasive and coherent design documentation.


 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"51b273c9dbd21c10358b403c3a961964","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Studio 2b Assignment 2 (5% Group, 40% Individual)","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"45","description":"

(4 week project)

In this project students are to interpret how cultural  and social rituals can enhance the products of our everyday dining life. They are to reserach  and analyse these social/cultural rituals as well as understanding the history of the ritual and how people interact and are socially and culturally bound by these rituals. They are then to design a product  that will respect the history and culture of the ritual as well as past and future social behaviours of users. Through the implementation of  a thorough design process, they are to design a product for a past or future ritual.  Functional aspects of this design through the process of conceptualisation, drawings and sketch model making will be used, with attention to technical details and material,  for manufacturing (design for real life).

The project requirements include , mood board, a series of development models, engineering drawings, process journal and written component. The group work component (research and design of a mood board) is 5% of the total mark.

Assessment weighting breakdown: 5% Group, 40% Individual.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"51b273c9dbd21c10358b403c3a961966","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"59b273c9dbd21c10358b403c3a961965","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5db273c9dbd21c10358b403c3a961964","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a1b273c9dbd21c10358b403c3a96197b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Studio 2b Assignment 1 (5% Group, 40% Individual)","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"45","description":"

(5 week project)

In this project students are to research and gain experience in analysing a specific user group. They are to identify the 'visual language' that links particular product designs to particular groups of users, and to determine design criteria that will assist in the design of particular products for a specific category of users (niche market/socio economic group) With the aim of successfully designing a product for a specific category of users and  to communicate the visual aspects of this design to a sample of those users in order to gain feedback on your work. This project will integrate acquired design studio skills to date, with a focus on technical details and materials and for manufacturing (design for real life). The project requirements include , mood board, a series of development models, engineering drawings, process journal and written component. The group work component (research and design of a mood board) is 5% of the total mark.

Assessment weighting breakdown: 5% Group, 40% Individual.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"51b273c9dbd21c10358b403c3a961966","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"59b273c9dbd21c10358b403c3a961965","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5db273c9dbd21c10358b403c3a961964","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"ddb273c9dbd21c10358b403c3a961967","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Studio 2b Assignment 3 – Process Journal","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"10","description":"

Students are asked to document thier design process through out the course term, this may be done digitally or in analogue form. It should include all sketches, images, quotes, mind maps, modelling and any other mode of visual communication to help develop designs. The process journal is to be submitted as a 1minute flick through video or padlet presentation

IDES2223 continues to develop students' Industrial Design process and build confidence in their methods and application of knowledge. A sequence of projects will include industry collaborations and introduction of specialised knowledge of market segments and production systems. Projects will increase in complexity and in the effectiveness of communication of Industrial Design outputs with visual, written and physical models. Learning from past and concurrent Design Theory course courses will be evident in the Industrial Design outcomes.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"29b9f98fdb831c50eb6b147a3a96192c","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project Three: User Research","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"10","description":"

This assessment task engages student groups to co-operate and collaborate in data collection in order to understand user behaviours, needs, and motivations; the data banks and user research reports are intended to catalyse and set the problem context for their individual design projects. Students will be assessed on the comprehensiveness, usefulness and relevance of their user research reports. Formative feedback will be given weekly during class and a summative feedback will be given after submission. This user research project is done as a group, but individual contributions will be assessed via Moodle Team Evaluation.

This assessment task challenges students to design packaging solutions that would help achieve the National Packaging Targets, which is to make 100% of packaging in Australia reusable, recyclable or compostable by 2025. The National Packaging Targets Project will involve ideation and product design development. Students will be assessed on the quality of their design process, design resolution, and design communication. Formative feedback will be given weekly during class and a summative feedback will be given after submission. This assessment task is individual.

This assessment task challenges students to design a product-based innovation that would help improve the lives and wellbeing of older people, their families, and the communities in which they live. The Healthy Ageing Project will involve ideation and product design development. Students will be assessed on the quality of their design process, design resolution, and design communication. Formative feedback will be given weekly during class and a summative feedback will be given after submission. This assessment task is individual.

Students in this course will learn from a range different perspectives, presented in lectures and readings, and a series of exercises in which they will analyse and evaluate issues and synthesise findings into new opportunities.

contentlets.description:
In todays world, problems are often complex, interrelated, dynamic and multifaceted. The role of design and innovation amid such complexity is crucial. Students in this course will learn from a range different perspectives, presented in lectures and readings, and a series of exercises in which they will analyse and evaluate issues and synthesise findings into new opportunities. 

Students will work collaboratively and iteratively using both visual representations and physical  mock-ups to arrive at design propositions that they have to pitch to the class. Learning from this course therefore supports students in proposing design interventions that encompass a wide scope of issues, are enduring and ultimately more successful.

This course is structured around lecture/demonstrations and practical computer lab classes in which students will learn various aspects of computer modelling and advanced techniques for communication of design ideas.  Building on CAD modelling skills already acquired, students will undertake exercises and project work based on design examples and presentation methods typical of industrial design practice. Learning from this course will support capability in subsequent design studio courses and professional practice.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"IDES3235 - Industrial Design in the Asian Century","description":"

‘Industrial Design in the Asian Century' is an intensive summer elective offered to students in the Bachelor of Industrial Design program. It involves observation visits to advanced manufacturing industries in a selected Asian country as well as collaborative problem solving workshops with industrial design students in an Asian partner university. The course provides an opportunity to be immersed not only in the Asian industrial design and manufacturing scene but also in the cultural traditions of Asia. The targeted Asian country changes every year. IDES3235 can be credited towards student’s ‘FBE Elective’ or ‘Open Elective’ requirements.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"ccab7c77dbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619b5","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Product pechakucha","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

PechaKucha (Japanese for ‘chit-chat’) is a concise and fast-paced presentation in which 20 slides are shown for 20 seconds each, thus totaling 6 minutes and 40 seconds. Choose a product theme to discuss, such as public transport vehicle interiors & exteriors, food retailing systems, traditional products in everyday life, vending systems; street furniture, culturally-unique packaging, 'thoughtless acts', etc. 

Take lots of pictures of objects and design details about your chosen topic. Write an essay-script on the topic and weave your images around the script to form your PechaKucha presentation. As you narrate the script, the automatically-changing images in the presentation should synchronize with your statements. The images should visually support the story and the script, not the other way around. 

Ensure that photographed items have a uniquely Asian identity and are considerably different from designs and systems commonly found in Australia. Original own photographs only: no downloaded images! Compose your images into a narrated PechaKucha presentation, then save as an AVI movie. Share on YouTube as an 'unlisted' video. 

Marks will be based on: the quality of PechaKucha subject (interesting, educational, thoroughly discussed, entertaining); the quality of content (information clearly presented; language properly and effectively used; images and graphics relate well to content; student demonstrated thoughtful approach to subject); and the quality of technical aspects (camera subject framed well, clearly visible; images well composed; clear and understandable sound; story effectively edited and flows well).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"48ab7c77dbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619ac","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"84ab7c77dbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619af","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"239b7c77dbf51c50eb6b147a3a961948","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Reflection Travelogue","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Contemplate on your various experiences from the places and events visited during this overseas course. Write an illustrated day-to-day account of your learning activities during the 14-day journey. Each daily account should end with a short reflection and deep thinking of how the learning activity of that day might have contributed to your growth as an industrial designer.

Be creative with this reflection assignment. Illustrate it with images showing your active participation and your unique memories. Lay it out like a photobook of images and reflective insights. Words at least 2,000; illustrated pages at least 30. Share on Google Drive AND submit as hardcopy photo-book.

Marks will be based on: the quality of content and expression (accurate recall and documentation of course activities; honest expression of thoughts and feelings; writing well composed, clear, concise and grammatically correct; thoughts expressed coherently and logically; meaningful images and graphic layout);  and the quality of reflective thinking (gained skills, knowledge and insights identified and evaluated through scrutiny of own actions; clear and in-depth personalized description of the intellectual and emotional response to the learning experience; evidence that student has questioned or evaluated their prior perceptions or beliefs; corrective future actions proposed).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"3f9b7c77dbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619a9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"48ab7c77dbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619ac","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"84ab7c77dbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619af","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"c0ab7c77dbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619b2","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6b9b7c77dbf51c50eb6b147a3a96194c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Pre-travel scrapbook","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"10","description":"

Before departing for the Asian destination each student will be assigned topics or sites to do preliminary research on, and to compile a ‘digital scrapbook’ about the topic which contains: a compilation of JPG images of exteriors, interiors, notable details; and a compilation of PDFs of e-brochures of highlights, significance, maps, etc. Submissions will be shared on Google Drive so as to be accessible to all participants. Using the collected information, each student will serve as a ‘resource person’ during the study tour for each location that he/she researched on.

Marks will be based on: the quantity and comprehensiveness of collected information; and the quality of collected JPGs and PDFs.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"48ab7c77dbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619ac","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"84ab7c77dbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619af","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b39b7c77dbf51c50eb6b147a3a961951","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Street photography","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"30","description":"

Shoot at least 500 high-quality images of various activities during the course. Share on Google Drive.

Apart from most days when the class is travelling as a group, there will be a few days designated as ‘Scavenger Hunt Days’, in which you will freely explore Asian cities with you travel buddies. The objective is to ‘collect’ the ‘items’ on the provided scavenger list by taking lots of pictures of them. Some snapshots submitted for this assessment task could be used for completing the other assessment tasks.

Your 500 photos should be completely different from each other. There should be no ‘duplicates’ or highly similar shots of the same object or event, or minor variations such as taking from a slightly different angle. All categories must be collected.

The 'scavenger hunt' list include: culture districts; historic, folk, and contemporary artifacts; technological breakthroughs; cultural performances; everyday life; public outdoor art; public and private transport; sustainable activities and systems; natural landscapes, seasonal colours; evening illumination; Culinary products, street foods; Asian architectural details (religious, royal, vernacular, contemporary); bird’s eye-view of Asian cities; and IDES3235 class activities.

Be sensitive with photo-taking. Seek permission from your photo subjects when practicable. See these tips on street photography.

Marks will be based on: the technical quality of images (clarity, lighting, focus, color, etc); and the content quality of images (composition, subject choice, visual impact).

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"IDES3321","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"IDES3321 - Design Studio 3A","description":"

IDES3321 Design Studio 3A focuses on the capacity of industrial design to address complex and pressing issues in the real world and highlights the ecological and social responsibilities of the industrial designer. The course emphasizes sustainable systems thinking and lifecycle thinking and develops design competence beyond purely commercial objectives. Each undertaking is expected to demonstrate a high level of technical resolution and documentation, and a rigorous engagement with the environmental and societal issues that are seen as opportunities for design intervention.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"002dedb7dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961981","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 2: Sustainable Development Goals (Individual)","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"45","description":"

Your challenge in Task 2 is to design a sustainable product or product service system that would address a United Nations Sustainable Development Goals target and indicator, and that considers ecological sustainability, social impact and economic viability, and relevant to the Australian context. This assessment task is individual.

During final presentations, you will be summatively assessed on the final design solution and communication, as well as the overall design process undertaken.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"bb1dedb7dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961977","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f71dedb7dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96197a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2f1dedb7dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961950","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 3: Learning Reflections (Individual)","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"10","description":"

This individual task requires you to think back over the learning impact of the resources you watched or read, and how the insights you gained might help you in your future career as an industrial designer. Marks will be based on clarity of expression, quality of insights, and introspection of the learning gained.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"042dedb7dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96197d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"771dedb7dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961955","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 1: Collaborative Circular Economy (Individual)","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"45","description":"

Your challenge in Task 1 is to design an innovative tangible product element or component that would enhance or enable a collaborative consumption or sustainable product service system, such that community members are enabled or empowered into adopting more environmentally positive and socially responsible consumption behaviours. This assessment task is individual.

During final presentations, you will be summatively assessed on the final design solution and communication, as well as the overall design process undertaken.

IDES3321 focuses on applying and synthesising knowledge gained from previous courses to prepare students for industry practice and working on projects that consider commercial requirements and constraints. This studio course will highlight the necessity for a refined design process within a commercial framework. Projects allow students to gain further experience in applying research and design methodologies to produce outcomes that address technical and manufacturing constraints while at the same time prioritising social, consumer and market needs. Each undertaking has a strong emphasis on innovation, technical resolution and high-level design documentation to a professional standard. A rigorous and responsible approach to product design is fostered by addressing real-world consumer, environmental, social, commercial, technological and manufacturing needs.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"4781ad3bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961936","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project 3: Digital twin","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

This project will explore the emergent field of the Internet of Things (IoT). It combines product design with the virtual representation of sensor data and visualisation technologies - a digital twin. We will be looking at sensors, networks, data in the cloud and dashboards nad how they can bring new transformative opportunities to product design. Students will present their work in a variety of formats, including verbal presentation, design drawings and presentation boards for assessment.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"3a81ad3bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961920","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"4781ad3bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961923","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"4b81ad3bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961932","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"fa81ad3bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96191d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3681ad3bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961914","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project 1: Student learning spaces (group work)","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

This project will involves collaboration with a project partner to explore new design solutions. Students will produce concept designs
and mock-up and design documentation. Students will present their work in a variety of formats, including verbal presentation, design drawings and presentation boards for assessment.

The course focuses on design research and design research methods, in preparation for the final capstone project in the following term. Students will develop research knowledge and skills, as they produce a substantive design research report based upon an agreed topic. The report, covering problem and/or opportunity identification, data gathering, synthesis and analysis of information and research results will conclude with a design brief, and proposals to guide the capstone project the following term in IDES4112. In parallel with the research focus, there will be studio activities offering different problem-solving approaches and providing a means for students to improve and perfect their design process.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"da725573dbf91c50eb6b147a3a961979","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project 3 - Three Futures","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

Use of design techniques (future-thinking, single finding concept creation, and design semantics) to develop three design concepts to address possible futures envisioned through
research project. • Imagining futures and trends
• Single key finding concepts and identifying nuggets and duds in each
• Understanding design semantics and form language
• Refining concepts
Presenting three concepts

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"0e725573dbf91c50eb6b147a3a96193b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ce725573dbf91c50eb6b147a3a961975","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3d725573dbf91c50eb6b147a3a96191c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project 1 - Researching with People","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"5","description":"

Understand and build empathy with people involved in the design research topic through the use of design research tools. Includes 1 interview and 2 other design tools.
• Developing a research plan.
• Presentation of research methods chosen
• Carrying out design research with people
• Analyzing data
• Presenting findings

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"0e725573dbf91c50eb6b147a3a96193b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"82725573dbf91c50eb6b147a3a961973","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ce725573dbf91c50eb6b147a3a961975","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"75725573dbf91c50eb6b147a3a961921","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Capstone Research Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"70","description":"

1. Two marking copies of your final Project Research Report (spiral bound is fine)
2. Your reflective process journal describing your design process (both for Research Report and Studio Projects modes).
3. A copy of your signed supervision log.
4. Your peer group joint reflection report (a few paragraphs).
Liaise with your peer group members to write this reflection together (= one report per peer group). This reflection should address how successful or not have your group meetings been, whether you benefited from it or not, and how things could have been improved.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"0e725573dbf91c50eb6b147a3a96193b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"46725573dbf91c50eb6b147a3a961970","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"82725573dbf91c50eb6b147a3a961973","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ce725573dbf91c50eb6b147a3a961975","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"75725573dbf91c50eb6b147a3a961932","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project 2 - Co-Design","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

Co-design is a valuable design research method that enables potential users to participate in the design process and help co-create design solutions.
• Working with the people who will potentially benefit from the potential product, to better understand and integrate their
needs into the designs.
• Documenting the co-design research (photos, videos, notes)
• Writing up key findings from the experience. This includes the feedback received from co-designer(s) both spoken and
unspoken (facial expressions, attitude, how they handled the mock-ups, etc).
• Reflecting on what was useful, what wasn't.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"0e725573dbf91c50eb6b147a3a96193b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"82725573dbf91c50eb6b147a3a961973","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ce725573dbf91c50eb6b147a3a961975","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"f1725573dbf91c50eb6b147a3a961918","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/IDES4100.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"","links":[]}

Advanced Studio provides students in the honours year with the opportunity to engage with design projects with a degree of complexity that will help prepare for their own Capstone Project and future design practice. Design projects for exploration will generally be defined with input from an industry partner, providing opportunity for simultaneous consideration of multiple stake-holders, technology, manufacture and a business model. Presentation and evaluation of work will include feedback from industry partners as well as academic evaluation of tasks undertaken.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"502e697bdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961932","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment task 1 - Project Progress and reflective Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"70","description":"

During the term you will create and contribute to a progressive online portfolio report. This will document and discuss your participation and contributions of your chosen project.  This will comprise of formative work you produce and document during weekly studio activities, together with a written reflection on your learning experiences at the conclusion of the course. You will be required to read and comment on the work of your fellow students. The online reflective report will be assessed at specified checkpoints during the term.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"182e697bdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96192b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"542e697bdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96192e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"8c2e297bdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619e4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8c2e297bdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619d6","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment task 2 Design documentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

This assessment is a presentation of the completed design documentation that you have prepared for your project collaborator. It may be undertaken in teams - as determined by the project partner - but is to be submitted individually by each student.

The main components of this presentation will be a technical information of the finalised design, complemented with context renderings, visuals and iterative prototypes.

This capstone project in the honours program is an opportunity to synthesise the skills and knowledge gained throughout the BID program. The work produced for this course will represent the culmination of studies in the program and provide an opportunity to demonstrate capabilities as an emerging design professional. This course builds directly upon the work undertaken in the previous term in IDES4100 Capstone Research. Previously learned skills and knowledge will be drawn upon and applied to a self-managed project that will 'showcase' the student's capabilities to potential employers.


.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"a24d3983dbc31c50eb6b147a3a9619b4","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Checkpoint 2","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

Checkpoint 2 builds on your delivery of Checkpoint 1 which determines the feasibility of your project proposal and assists the student with defining their project direction. This assessment is to review the student's preferred concepts. The student will present a distillation of concept designs prefaced by their design project statement. The student should not show any prior work from last semester and the quality of work should reflect approximately 30 hours per week effort for a 18 unit course.  

Students are expected to present their Design Statement, concept sketches and sketch models.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"624d7983dbc31c50eb6b147a3a96198b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"aa4d3983dbc31c50eb6b147a3a9619b6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"224d7983dbc31c50eb6b147a3a96198d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"60","description":"

Students are to present their Capstone design project to an assessment panel consisting of 3 assessors. Each student will be allocated a total of 25 minutes. Students will have up to 15 minutes to present their design and then 10 minutes for questions.

To complement their verbal presentation, the student will present a range of presentation visuals and associated materials including an appearance model or prototype. This will enable the student to clearly communicate a complete picture of their resolved design proposal. Additionally, the student is required to submit a Design Process Diary.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"624d7983dbc31c50eb6b147a3a96198b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"6a4d7983dbc31c50eb6b147a3a96198a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"6a4d7983dbc31c50eb6b147a3a96198b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"aa4d3983dbc31c50eb6b147a3a9619b6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"ae4d3983dbc31c50eb6b147a3a9619b5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"364d7983dbc31c50eb6b147a3a961997","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Supervisor Assessment","assessment_type":{"label":"Performance","value":"performance"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"10","description":"

Supervisors allocate a mark based on the student's performance throughout the semester taking into consideration the student's ability to work under supervision, take advice and critique, making the recommended amendments when required. The supervisor will also take into consideration the ability of the student to manage their time effectively in order to complete the project at an exemplary standard.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"6a4d7983dbc31c50eb6b147a3a96198a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"6a4d7983dbc31c50eb6b147a3a96198b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"ae4d3983dbc31c50eb6b147a3a9619b5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7a4d7983dbc31c50eb6b147a3a961992","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Checkpoint 3","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

The main components of this presentation will be a comprehensive GA (General Assembly) drawing complemented with renders of the external form and UX visuals and an accurate sketch model.  

Checkpoint 3 aims to identify the student's ability to convey the external form and visual language, internal and external arrangement of components of your preferred final design. The student should demonstrate a sufficient understanding and detail of appropriate technology packs and/or mechanisms, product function and user experience. This work should represent a distillation and realisation of design development undertaken since the commencement of the project.
